source.raw_text:
Wall Slides are an excellent mobility drill targeting the upper back (traps, rhomboids), shoulders (deltoids, rotator cuff), and serratus anterior, improving scapular stability, overhead reach, and posture by promoting upward shoulder rotation and decompressing the shoulder joint while engaging the core for stability. The movement pattern involves pressing forearms/hands against a wall and sliding them overhead, emphasizing controlled, slow motion to improve the shoulder's overhead movement and activate stabilizing muscles. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  
Muscles Worked 

• Upper Back: Trapezius (especially lower traps), Rhomboids (stabilize shoulder blades). 
• Shoulders: Deltoids, Rotator Cuff Muscles (for stability). 
• Serratus Anterior: Crucial for upward scapular rotation. 
• Core: Abdominals, Erector Spinae (maintain posture and prevent arching). [1, 3, 4, 5, 7]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Starting Position: Stand with your back, head, shoulders, and forearms/hands against a wall, elbows bent at 90 degrees (like a goalpost). 
2. The Slide: Slowly slide your arms overhead, trying to keep all points (back, forearms, hands) touching the wall, reaching as high as comfortable. 
3. Scapular Action: Focus on upwardly rotating the shoulder blades and depressing the humerus (bone in the upper arm). 
4. Controlled Return: Slowly lower arms back to the starting position, maintaining control and avoiding shrugging the shoulders. [1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 9]  

Key Focuses & Benefits 

• Improved Posture: Counteracts rounded shoulders by strengthening mid/upper back. 
• Enhanced Mobility: Increases range of motion for overhead activities. 
• Scapular Control: Teaches proper scapular movement (upward rotation). 
• Injury Prevention: Reduces strain by improving shoulder mechanics. [1, 3, 4, 5, 10]
